OS.content: Heidegger’s question of Being seeks to destroy vulgar concept of time by repeating and interrogating it > that Being is ousia, parousia, Anwesenheit w/ regard to idea of time as Gegenwart (the present)
OS.linkedContent: Heidegger’s question of Being seeks to destroy vulgar concept of time by repeating and interrogating it > that Being is ousia, parousia, Anwesenheit w/ regard to idea of time as Gegenwart (the present)

OS.content: vulgar time as gegenwärtigen Besitze (always present possession), the having (Habe) of Being, its permanent presence
OS.linkedContent: vulgar time as gegenwärtigen Besitze (always present possession), the having (Habe) of Being, its permanent presence

OS.content: [Heidegger’s footnote that links Hegel’s vulgar concept of time to Aristotle]
OS.linkedContent: [Heidegger’s footnote that links Hegel’s vulgar concept of time to Aristotle]

OS.content: is [Heidegger’s] authentic/inauthentic, proper/improper still Hegelian, still “vulgar” time
OS.linkedContent: is [Heidegger’s] authentic/inauthentic, proper/improper still Hegelian, still “vulgar” time

OS.content: Hegel: now [point] has tremendous right (ein ungeheures Recht), it is nothing as individual Now, as I pronounce it, the proudly exclusive now dissolves, flows away, falls into dust
OS.linkedContent: Hegel: now [point] has tremendous right (ein ungeheures Recht), it is nothing as individual Now, as I pronounce it, the proudly exclusive now dissolves, flows away, falls into dust

OS.content: acc. Heidegger, [MOP] privilege of form of “now” and “point”
OS.linkedContent: acc. Heidegger, [MOP] privilege of form of “now” and “point”

OS.content: Aristotle’s aporia [on time] is an exoteric: opened and closed on this dead end (cette voie sans issue): time is that which “is not” or “barely, and scarcely”
OS.linkedContent: Aristotle’s aporia [on time] is an exoteric: opened and closed on this dead end (cette voie sans issue): time is that which “is not” or “barely, and scarcely”

OS.content: “there is no chance that within the thematic of metaphysics anything might have budged” w/ respect to concept of time, from Aristotle to Hegel > founding concepts, entire system, substance, cause, etc. sufficed > one cannot interrupt, transgress, exceed “metaphysics” w/out acknowledging this powerful systematic truth
OS.linkedContent: “there is no chance that within the thematic of metaphysics anything might have budged” w/ respect to concept of time, from Aristotle to Hegel > founding concepts, entire system, substance, cause, etc. sufficed > one cannot interrupt, transgress, exceed “metaphysics” w/out acknowledging this powerful systematic truth

OS.content: nun, often translated as instant, functions in Greek like “now (maintenant)” > nun is form in which time cannot not be given, yet nun is not, is both no longer (n’est plus) & not yet (n’est pas encore), a no-thing (ne-ant), doesn’t participate in presence
OS.linkedContent: nun, often translated as instant, functions in Greek like “now (maintenant)” > nun is form in which time cannot not be given, yet nun is not, is both no longer (n’est plus) & not yet (n’est pas encore), a no-thing (ne-ant), doesn’t participate in presence

OS.content: 1st stage of Aristotle’s aporia [re: time]: think time as divisibility, where none of its parts, no now, is in the present; 2nd stage: now is not a part, time is not composed of nun
OS.linkedContent: 1st stage of Aristotle’s aporia [re: time]: think time as divisibility, where none of its parts, no now, is in the present; 2nd stage: now is not a part, time is not composed of nun

OS.content: space becomes concrete by retaining/restoring negative w/in itself, by negating itself
OS.linkedContent: space becomes concrete by retaining/restoring negative w/in itself, by negating itself

OS.content: 1st negative determination of space is the POINT (the place that does not take place), it then negates itself in relation the LINE > als sich aufhebend, point is the line, the Being-spatial of point > then comes the PLANE (surface) > each next stage only made of the negated prior stage, i.e. line made of negated points
OS.linkedContent: 1st negative determination of space is the POINT (the place that does not take place), it then negates itself in relation the LINE > als sich aufhebend, point is the line, the Being-spatial of point > then comes the PLANE (surface) > each next stage only made of the negated prior stage, i.e. line made of negated points

OS.content: “always too late to ask the question of time” re: spatialization
OS.linkedContent: “always too late to ask the question of time” re: spatialization

OS.content: each stage of Aufhebung is time
OS.linkedContent: each stage of Aufhebung is time

OS.content: point & time thought in circularity together (Aufhebung, speculative negativity, only possible by means of infinite correlation or reflection) > time is spacing, space is time > thus for Aristotle, stigmē, punctuality, determines nowness (nun, jetzt)
OS.linkedContent: point & time thought in circularity together (Aufhebung, speculative negativity, only possible by means of infinite correlation or reflection) > time is spacing, space is time > thus for Aristotle, stigmē, punctuality, determines nowness (nun, jetzt)

OS.content: Hegel: negativity posited for-itself is time
OS.linkedContent: Hegel: negativity posited for-itself is time

OS.content: acc. Hegel, negation of negation as punctuality is time, time relève space
OS.linkedContent: acc. Hegel, negation of negation as punctuality is time, time relève space

OS.content: Hegel credits Kant w/ discovering “non-sensuous sensuous” concept of time, “intuited becoming” in itself, w/out empirical sensory content [Copernican revolution]
OS.linkedContent: Hegel credits Kant w/ discovering “non-sensuous sensuous” concept of time, “intuited becoming” in itself, w/out empirical sensory content [Copernican revolution]

OS.content: Heidegger, like Hegel, equates I = I w/ time, in the form “I think” is time
OS.linkedContent: Heidegger, like Hegel, equates I = I w/ time, in the form “I think” is time

OS.content: for Hegel, time is becoming/passing away, not simply that in which things pass away > Hegel critiques “fall” into time, intratemporality (Innerzeitigkeit) (but, Derrida adds, this “fall” shouldn’t be denied all dignity, see WM)
OS.linkedContent: for Hegel, time is becoming/passing away, not simply that in which things pass away > Hegel critiques “fall” into time, intratemporality (Innerzeitigkeit) (but, Derrida adds, this “fall” shouldn’t be denied all dignity, see WM)

OS.content: acc. Hegel, think present as eternity, eternity as another name of the presence of the present (eternal, Idea, Spirit, True, neither inside nor outside time)
OS.linkedContent: acc. Hegel, think present as eternity, eternity as another name of the presence of the present (eternal, Idea, Spirit, True, neither inside nor outside time)

OS.content: Hegel: immediate vanishing of differences [re: dimensions of time as becoming externality: past, future, present] into singularity is the present as Now (die Gegenwart als Jetzt) > vanishing of being into nothing & nothing into being: excludes/continues other moments
OS.linkedContent: Hegel: immediate vanishing of differences [re: dimensions of time as becoming externality: past, future, present] into singularity is the present as Now (die Gegenwart als Jetzt) > vanishing of being into nothing & nothing into being: excludes/continues other moments

OS.content: [Kant & Aristotle treat time as pure form of sensibility (nonsensuous sensuous), because time does not belong to beings]
OS.linkedContent: [Kant & Aristotle treat time as pure form of sensibility (nonsensuous sensuous), because time does not belong to beings]

OS.content: time compared by Aristotle to movement and chance, w/out being either one of them, time can only occur en tēi psukhēi > time’s analogy: what is traced (le tracé) as line, grammē
OS.linkedContent: time compared by Aristotle to movement and chance, w/out being either one of them, time can only occur en tēi psukhēi > time’s analogy: what is traced (le tracé) as line, grammē

OS.content: time, for Kant, brings difference together: only in time can opposed predicates meet in same object
OS.linkedContent: time, for Kant, brings difference together: only in time can opposed predicates meet in same object

OS.content: for Kant, inner intuition of time gives us no shape, so we make up for this via analogy: time is a line progressing to infinity > but where parts of line are simultaneous, parts of time are successive
OS.linkedContent: for Kant, inner intuition of time gives us no shape, so we make up for this via analogy: time is a line progressing to infinity > but where parts of line are simultaneous, parts of time are successive

OS.content: if Aristotle conceived time in a way not dominated by presence, did Heidegger arrest this possibility in Sein und Zeit, did Kant just make explicit the evaded question [section title] in Physics IV? such making explicit keeps to (se tient) the system de l’éludé
OS.linkedContent: if Aristotle conceived time in a way not dominated by presence, did Heidegger arrest this possibility in Sein und Zeit, did Kant just make explicit the evaded question [section title] in Physics IV? such making explicit keeps to (se tient) the system de l’éludé

OS.content: Heidegger: Kant’s transcendental aesthetic can’t perceive something actually present (Anwesenden), to perceive something Gegenwärtigen, one couldn’t intuit a single now (Jetzt), since each now has essentially continuous extension in just passing and just coming (in sein Soeben und Sogleich)
OS.linkedContent: Heidegger: Kant’s transcendental aesthetic can’t perceive something actually present (Anwesenden), to perceive something Gegenwärtigen, one couldn’t intuit a single now (Jetzt), since each now has essentially continuous extension in just passing and just coming (in sein Soeben und Sogleich)

OS.content: Aristotle repeats aporia of Zeno’s argument re: time, says it clarifies nothing, but does not deconstruct it > time’s nonbeing pre-comprehended as nonpresence in relation to determination of being as present
OS.linkedContent: Aristotle repeats aporia of Zeno’s argument re: time, says it clarifies nothing, but does not deconstruct it > time’s nonbeing pre-comprehended as nonpresence in relation to determination of being as present

OS.content: to say time is not present is to already have determined time as “now”
OS.linkedContent: to say time is not present is to already have determined time as “now”

OS.content: question of meaning (sens) always posed w/in closure of metaphysics: sens (meaning, essence) governed by ousia as presence, as act, as end of movement, energeia (the sens of time thought on basis of present as nontime, as Being)
OS.linkedContent: question of meaning (sens) always posed w/in closure of metaphysics: sens (meaning, essence) governed by ousia as presence, as act, as end of movement, energeia (the sens of time thought on basis of present as nontime, as Being)

OS.content: [re: ousia as presence] Hegel makes Aristotle’s nonpresence of time explicit by calling it negativity
OS.linkedContent: [re: ousia as presence] Hegel makes Aristotle’s nonpresence of time explicit by calling it negativity

OS.content: all anticipation of the meaning of time: onto-theo-teleology; time suppressed the moment one asks the question of its meaning, when one relates it to presence, truth, essence; Hegel: “time is that which erases time” > time, existence of circle, hides from itself its own totality
OS.linkedContent: all anticipation of the meaning of time: onto-theo-teleology; time suppressed the moment one asks the question of its meaning, when one relates it to presence, truth, essence; Hegel: “time is that which erases time” > time, existence of circle, hides from itself its own totality

OS.content: for Aristotle, circle is model of movement for time and grammē
OS.linkedContent: for Aristotle, circle is model of movement for time and grammē

OS.content: for Hegel, time erases time, Tilgen (to erase) is also an Aufhebung: given that time is pure exterior self, parousia is end of time
OS.linkedContent: for Hegel, time erases time, Tilgen (to erase) is also an Aufhebung: given that time is pure exterior self, parousia is end of time

OS.content: acc. Aristotle, time is continuous & divided according to the “now” [does Hegel simply affirm Aristotle’s exoteric aporia?]
OS.linkedContent: acc. Aristotle, time is continuous & divided according to the “now” [does Hegel simply affirm Aristotle’s exoteric aporia?]

OS.content: the now, presence in the act of the present: l’impossibilité de coexister avec soi: avec soi, c’est-à-dire, avec un autre soi, un autre maintenant, un autre même, un double
OS.linkedContent: the now, presence in the act of the present: l’impossibilité de coexister avec soi: avec soi, c’est-à-dire, avec un autre soi, un autre maintenant, un autre même, un double

OS.content: this impossibility contradicts itself, time is name for possibility of impossible, this impossible possibility: alterity & identity of the now maintained in a differentiated element of a certain same
OS.linkedContent: this impossibility contradicts itself, time is name for possibility of impossible, this impossible possibility: alterity & identity of the now maintained in a differentiated element of a certain same

OS.content: the cum, or co- of coexsistence has meaning only on basis of its impossibility
OS.linkedContent: the cum, or co- of coexsistence has meaning only on basis of its impossibility

OS.content: conversely, space of possible coexistence is space of impossible coexistence > simultaneity only via synthesis, temporal complicity [cumplicity]
OS.linkedContent: conversely, space of possible coexistence is space of impossible coexistence > simultaneity only via synthesis, temporal complicity [cumplicity]

OS.content: for Aristotle, being-together [of nun and stigmē] not a determination of Being but very production of Being > ama as the pivot (cheville) (clavis), the key opening & closing metaphysics > this complicity so self-effacing as to barely be noticed, the common origin of space & time
OS.linkedContent: for Aristotle, being-together [of nun and stigmē] not a determination of Being but very production of Being > ama as the pivot (cheville) (clavis), the key opening & closing metaphysics > this complicity so self-effacing as to barely be noticed, the common origin of space & time

OS.content: Aristotle’s 1st aporia, nun not part of ousia, because made of now’s (time’s parts), several nows can’t : 1) follow each other by immediately destroying each other 2) not destroy each other immediately 3) or remain in the same now > need temporal intemporal hama to conceive this aporia
OS.linkedContent: Aristotle’s 1st aporia, nun not part of ousia, because made of now’s (time’s parts), several nows can’t : 1) follow each other by immediately destroying each other 2) not destroy each other immediately 3) or remain in the same now > need temporal intemporal hama to conceive this aporia

OS.content: [quoting Aristotle, Derrida doesn’t concur w/ Bergson’s critique of Aristotelian time as cinematographic > Aristotle can’t identity time w/ gramme representing movement]
OS.linkedContent: [quoting Aristotle, Derrida doesn’t concur w/ Bergson’s critique of Aristotelian time as cinematographic > Aristotle can’t identity time w/ gramme representing movement]

OS.content: Aristotle: [strange logic re: now as limit, whereas no determinate divisible thing has a unique limit]
OS.linkedContent: Aristotle: [strange logic re: now as limit, whereas no determinate divisible thing has a unique limit]

OS.content: for Aristotle, time defines movement/change (not defined by them)
OS.linkedContent: for Aristotle, time defines movement/change (not defined by them)

OS.content: analogy, correspondence: enigma of “at the same time” [re: relation of time to space, changes of place, movement]

OS.content: Bergson: traditionally, one studies space & transports conclusions to time: juxtaposition (space) replaced by succession (time), space & time treated symmetrically
OS.linkedContent: Bergson: traditionally, one studies space & transports conclusions to time: juxtaposition (space) replaced by succession (time), space & time treated symmetrically

OS.content: Aristotle differentiates numbering # [actual #] from that which can be numbered (horse, man, time), time thus not a mathematical being
OS.linkedContent: Aristotle differentiates numbering # [actual #] from that which can be numbered (horse, man, time), time thus not a mathematical being

OS.content: for Aristotle, the point gives to length its continuity and limit, an end and a beginning (arkhē kai teleutē); but ‘now’ is not to time what point is to line, because successive arrests does not give time (ne donne pas le temps); instead, now is neither time’s origin, end or limit (to the extent that it belongs to time) > instead, must conceive of gramme [French] not as line (by way of its parts or points) but as a line in act, by way of its extremities (ta eskhata)
OS.linkedContent: for Aristotle, the point gives to length its continuity and limit, an end and a beginning (arkhē kai teleutē); but ‘now’ is not to time what point is to line, because successive arrests does not give time (ne donne pas le temps); instead, now is neither time’s origin, end or limit (to the extent that it belongs to time) > instead, must conceive of gramme [French] not as line (by way of its parts or points) but as a line in act, by way of its extremities (ta eskhata)

OS.content: this would be a gramme that erases its tracing in a circle, removes limit of point
OS.linkedContent: this would be a gramme that erases its tracing in a circle, removes limit of point

OS.content: we go around in circles trying to erase this circle > [time, still, introduces the thought of trace, if even to excise it]
OS.linkedContent: we go around in circles trying to erase this circle > [time, still, introduces the thought of trace, if even to excise it]

OS.content: like “point: line,” now as limit (peras) is only time’s accident, time not thought on basis of now, thus mathematization of time has limits (always accidents/potentialities) [taken in all senses]
